channel.title: Cancer Features
channel.description: An RSS feed of features from CDC's Division of Cancer Prevention and Control.

item.title: Cervical Cancer Awareness
item.description: Most cases of cervical cancer are easily preventable with regular screening tests and follow-up. It also is highly curable when found and treated early. Vaccines are available to protect against the most common cause of cervical cancer.

item.title: Cancer, the Flu, and You
item.description: Living with cancer increases your risk for complications from the flu. People with cancer or a history of cancer, and people who live with or care for cancer patients and survivors, should get a flu shot every year.

item.title: Preventing Infections in Cancer Patients
item.description: Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy are more likely to get an infection. For these people, any type of infection may become serious quickly. If you have cancer and are receiving chemotherapy, learn the facts about infection.

item.title: Using Science to Prevent Cancer
item.description: Recent publications including findings on liver cancer, tobacco-related cancers, the potential impact of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine on cancers in the United States, and prevention of cancer starting before birth.

item.title: Lung Cancer Awareness
item.description: To lower your lung cancer risk, quit smoking, avoid secondhand smoke and get your home tested for radon.

item.title: Breast Cancer in Young Women
item.description: Most breast cancers are found in women who are 50 years old or older, but breast cancer also affects younger women. Some young women are at a higher risk for getting breast cancer at an early age compared with other women their age. Find out if you may have risk factors.

item.title: Breast Cancer Awareness
item.description: The best way to find breast cancer early is with a mammogram. If you are 50 to 74 years old, be sure to have a screening mammogram every two years. If you are 40 to 49 years old, talk to your doctor about when to start and how often to get a screening mammogram.

item.title: Gynecologic Cancer Awareness
item.description: Learn about the symptoms and risk factors for cervical, ovarian, uterine, vaginal, and vulvar cancers. When gynecologic cancers are found early, treatment works best.

item.title: Prostate Cancer Awareness
item.description: Prostate cancer is the most non-skin common cancer in men. Most prostate cancers grow slowly, and don't cause any health problems in men who have them. Learn about prostate cancer and talk to your doctor before you decide to get tested or treated.

item.title: Cancer Prevention Starts in Childhood
item.description: Reduce your children's risk of getting many types of cancer later in life.

item.title: Cancer and Men
item.description: Every year, cancer claims the lives of nearly 300,000 men in America. Men can reduce their risk for several of the most common kinds of cancer.

item.title: Improving Health and Quality of Life After Cancer
item.description: At least one-third of the more than 14 million survivors in the United States face physical, mental, social, job, or financial problems related to their cancer experience. Learn what can be done.

item.title: Skin Cancer Awareness
item.description: While you enjoy the outdoors this summer, protect yourself from skin cancer.

item.title: Cancer and Women
item.description: Women can reduce their cancer risk by adopting a healthy lifestyle and getting the right cancer screening tests for their stage of life.

item.title: Health Disparities in Cancer
item.description: Increasing early cancer detection, promoting healthy lifestyles, and expanding access to health care help reduce inequalities in cancer among groups at greatest risk.

item.title: Colorectal Cancer Awareness
item.description: Among cancers that affect both men and women, colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States.

item.title: Cancer Prevention in the Workplace
item.description: Making sure that workers are safe on the job and creating a culture that supports healthy behaviors can improve employee health, safety, and well-being.

item.title: CDC Vital Signs: Cervical Cancer Is Preventable
item.description: More than 12,000 women in the United States get cervical cancer every year, even though up to 93% of these cancers could be prevented by screening and HPV (human papillomavirus) vaccination. Learn what can be done to reduce the burden of cervical cancer.

item.title: The Surgeon General's Call to Action to Prevent Skin Cancer
item.description: Individuals, communities, policymakers, and state and federal governments all have a role to play in preventing skin cancer.

item.title: Know:BRCA
item.description: The Know:BRCA tool can help you learn about BRCA genes and assess your risk of having a BRCA mutation.

item.title: The Burning Truth
item.description: Avoiding indoor tanning and protecting yourself from the sun when outdoors are the best ways to reduce your chance of getting skin cancer.
